{{Infobox musical artist | name = Duke Henderson | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Sylvester C. Henderson{{cite web |url=http://www.secondhandsongs.com/artist/39022 Secondhandsongs.com |title=Artist: Duke Henderson |year=2010 |publisher=Second Hand Songs |accessdate=9 November 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.goofinrecords.com/shop/index.php?topic=45 |publisher=Goofin Records |title=Al "Cake" Wichard Sextette - Cake Walkin' - The Modern Recordings 1947-1948 |last=Rounce |first=Tony |accessdate=9 November 2010}} | alias = | birth_date = | death_date = 1972
[[Los Angeles]], [[California]], [[United States]] | origin = | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]] | genre = [[Blues]], [[jazz]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]] | years_active = 1945–1953{{cite web |url=http://www.lordisco.com/musicians/H11.html |publisher=Lordisco.com |title=Musician List |accessdate=9 November 2010}} | label = Various including [[Apollo Records (1944)|Apollo Records]] | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Duke Henderson''' (died 1972), born '''Sylvester C. Henderson''', was an [[United States|American]] [[blues shouter]] and [[jazz]] [[singing|singer]] in the mid-1940s. His styles included [[West Coast blues]] and [[jump blues]]. In the late 1940s he renounced his past and began broadcasting as a [[Minister (Christianity)|minister]] and [[gospel music|gospel]] [[Disc jockey|DJ]]. He eventually became a preacher. ==Music career== In 1945 Henderson made his debut [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] with the [[New York City|New York]] based [[Apollo Records (1944)|Apollo]] [[record label|label]]. [[Jack McVea]] recommended Henderson to the label, and he was backed on the recording dates by several notable [[Los Angeles]] [[session musician]]s. These included McVea, [[Wild Bill Moore]] and [[Lucky Thompson]] ([[saxophone]]s), [[Gene Phillips]] ([[guitar]]), [[Shifty Henry]] and [[Charles Mingus|Charlie Mingus]] ([[bass violin]]), plus [[Lee Young]] and Rabon Tarrant ([[drum]]s). The recordings were not a commercial success and Henderson lost his recording contract with Apollo. In 1947 [[Al "Cake" Wichard]] recorded for [[Modern Records]] billed as the Al Wichard Sextette, and featured vocals by Henderson. Henderson subsequently recorded material for a number of labels over several years. His work was released by Globe, Down Beat, [[Swing Time Records|Swing Time]], [[Specialty Records|Specialty]] ("Country Girl" b/w "Lucy Brown", October 1952),{{cite web |url=http://www.globaldogproductions.info/s/specialty.html |publisher=Global Dog Productions |accessdate=9 November 2010 |title=Discography for Specialty Records |year=2006}} Modern, and [[Imperial Records|Imperial]]. Henderson ended up at [[Flair Records]], where his 1953 release, "Hey Mr. Kinsey", was billed as recorded by Big Duke, and displayed a knowledge of the then [[Kinsey Reports|current thinking]] on [[human sexual activity]]. Later in the decade, Henderson renounced his past, and commenced broadcasting on [[XERB-AM | XERB]] billed as Brother Henderson. His [[Minister (Christianity)|ministrial]] gospel DJ career there was short-lived, although the [[radio station]] was later utilised by [[Wolfman Jack]].{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=duke-henderson-p142904/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Duke Henderson |last=Dahl |first=Bill |year=2010|publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=2 November 2010}} In the late 1950s Henderson broadcast with [[KTNQ|KPOP]] in Los Angeles. After his DJ career, Henderson went on to become a preacher.{{cite web |url=http://www.rootsandrhythm.com/roots/BLUES%20&%20GOSPEL/blues_h2.htm |title=Duke Henderson - Get Your Kicks |publisher=Roots & Rhythm|year=2010|accessdate=2 November 2010}} In February 1959 ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' reported that Proverb Records was being jointly formed by Brother Henderson. By 1964 its subsidiary label, Gospel Corner, was initiated.{{cite web |url=http://www.justmovingon.info/LABELS/Proverb.html |title=Proverb |author= |publisher=Justmovingon.info|accessdate=2 November 2010}} Henderson died in Los Angeles in 1972. In 1994 [[Delmark Records|Delmark]] issued a [[compilation album|compilation]] [[Compact disc|CD]], containing 20 tracks from Henderson's late 1945 Apollo recordings. ==Compilation album== {| class="wikitable sortable" !Album title !Record label !Year of release |- |''Get Your Kicks'' |[[Delmark Records]] |1994 |- |}{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=get-your-kicks-r205861|pure_url=yes}} |title=Get Your Kicks: Review |last=Dahl |first=Bill |year=2010 |accessdate=9 November 2010 |publisher=All Music}} ==See also== *[[List of West Coast blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control|VIAF=24234512}} {{Persondata | NAME = Henderson, Duke | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = Henderson, Sylvester C. | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[blues shouter]] and [[jazz]] singer | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1972 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], [[United States]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Henderson, Duke}} [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:Place of birth missing]] [[Category:1972 deaths]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American jazz singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:West Coast blues musicians]] [[Category:Jump blues musicians]]
